==Chinese==
{{zh-forms|alt=靑,𤯞}}

===Glyph origin===
{{Han etym}}
{{Han compound|生|t1=growth of plants|丹|t2=cinnabar|ls=ic}}. Cinnabar was used for dyeing, and by extension, came to imply “color” in general, giving the combined meaning “color of growing plants” → “blue-green”.

Top component is cognate to {{zh-l|*生}}, but bottom component now resembles the unrelated {{zh-l|*月|moon}}.

===Definitions===
{{zh-hanzi}}

# [[blue-green]]; [[blue]] (of sky, stone etc.); [[green]] (of grass, plants, mountain etc.)
# [[blue-green]]-coloured [[item]]s
# [[black]] (of hair, cloth, silk thread etc.)
# [[luxuriant]]; [[lush]]; [[exuberant]]
# [[young]]; [[adolescent]]
# [[east]]
# [[spring]]
# [[green]] [[grass]]
# [[ripening]] [[crops]]
# {{zh-short|青海|[[Qinghai]] Province}}
# {{surname|lang=zh}}

====Usage notes====
The meaning for “blue” and “black” is more commonly used in Classical Chinese, while in modern Chinese, the meaning for “green” is more common. For example, {{zh-l|*青山綠水|hill and water green in colour}}, {{zh-l|*青蘋果|green apple}}. However, there are still some expressions for the meaning of blue, e.g. {{zh-l|*青天|blue sky}}, {{zh-l|*青出於藍|blue comes from indigo; someone performing better than their teacher}}

In Cantonese the use of {{lang|zh|青}} to mean “black” is still used in circumstances where to use {{zh-l|黑|hak1}} would be inauspicious, as it is a near-homophone of {{zh-l|乞|hat1|beggar}}. For example, {{zh-l|黑衣|hak1 ji1}} used to describe clothing would be a near-homophone of both beggar and a beggar's garment.

===Etymology 1===
{{IPAchar|/sawo/}} {{qualifier|uncertain, may be compound as opposed to root}} → {{IPAchar|/awo/}} → {{IPAchar|/ao/}}

From {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=あお}}.

Appears as the latter part in older compounds with an ''-s-'' infix or prefix. It is unclear if this leading {{IPAchar|/s/}} is indicative of an earlier form (''sawo''), or if this was an addition for [[euphony]] to avoid vowel clusters, or for other reasons. This {{IPAchar|/s/}} is also seen in {{m|ja|雨|tr=ame|pos=becoming ''same'' in old compounds}} and {{m|ja|稲|tr=ine|pos=becoming ''shine'' in old compounds}}.

Given that this {{IPAchar|/s/}} only ever appears interstitially, and given the semantics, this {{IPAchar|/s/}} may be cognate with {{etyl|ko|-}} interfix {{m|ko|ᄉ|-ᄉ-|tr=-s-}} used to mark possession, much like {{cog|en|'s}}.
